Options.Value: The convergence of people from disparate regions results in the pressure of communication
There is title demand for the indigenous dialects
They want a lingua franca which is produced by mutual intelligibility
They are made up of both rural and urban dwellers.

Question 1.Question:
COMPREHENSION

Read the passage below carefully and answer the questions that follow.

PASSAGE

The emergence of a standard dialect produces the phenomenon known as’ accent’ which is quite different from dialect. In the process of learning a foreign language, it is normal to transfer the patterns of an indigenous language to those of the foreign language. With time, however, those of form and most of those of orthography and phonology gradually get eliminated. This is because these can easily be identified and corrected. They are easy to correct because they do not involve patterns of muscular movement. It is also necessary to correct them because otherwise they could seriously impair intelligibility.

With phonetic patterns, on the other hand, there is a great deal of intelligibility tolerance because muscular patterns are involved, thus making corrections difficult when observed. Besides, phonetic patterns do not impair intelligibility much. Hence the transference of phonetic habits from one language to another is both easier to tolerate and more difficult to avoid than transference at the lexicon-grammatical level. It follows that a speaker who is learning a second dialect does so with an accent since the muscles of his speech organs would have crystallized in response to the phonetics of his native language which he learnt first. The speaker therefore speaks the second dialect with the phonetic features of his native dialect. The learning of a standard language is simply the learning of a second dialect- that which has been standardized.

Members of a language community control at least two dialects and use both dialects in different situations. In rural areas, the native dialect is used in most situations since there is less movement. Therefore, rural dwellers tend to be parochial and maintain the homogeneity of their dialect. In the urban community, on the other hand, there is more demand on the standard dialect than on the rural one. This is because people from different regions converge here. In order to ensure mutual intelligibility resulting from the pressure of communication, a great deal of demand is made on the standard dialect which now becomes the lingua franca amongst them.

Members of a language community control at least two dialects because
Question 1.Explanation:
This can be seen in paragraph 3, last sentence.

“This is because people from different regions converge here. In order to ensure mutual intelligibility resulting from the pressure of communication, a great deal of demand is made on the standard dialect which now becomes the lingua franca amongst them”.

Options.Value: A foreign language produces the transference of the correct patterns of dialect features.
Speech organs are shaped by indigenous languages
A lingua franca is the consequence of a standard dialect
Mutual intelligibility is the consequence of the pressure of communication

Question 3.Explanation: It should be noted that what an essay is all about can be deduced both from its introduction and its conclusion. The first sentence of this essay explains what the write – up is all about and it goes further to give more information about the subject matter, standard language. Options.Value: He is now a dead man
He is moving rapidly into a long dark tunnel
He can only watch as the events unfold
His new ‘body’ would not allow him to participate

Question 6.Question:
PASSAGE

It is possible to have a glimpse of life after death. Man has always believed in an afterlife, but only today do we have scientific reports of people who seem to have experienced the sensation of dying but lived to tell about it. Ongoing research is documenting hundreds each year of the near-death experience (NDE) and scientists think they are finding a clearly identifiable pattern: usually a man is dying and as he reaches the point of greatest physical distress, he hears himself pronounced dead by his doctor. He begins to hear an uncomfortable noise ,a loud ringing or buzzing and at the same time, feels himself moving very rapidly through a dark tunnel. After this, he suddenly finds himself outside of his own physical body, but still in the immediate physical environment and he sees his own body from a distance as though he is a spectator. He watches the resuscitation attempt from his unusual vantage point and is in a state of emotional upheaval.

After a while, he collects himself and becomes more accustomed to this odd condition. He notices that he still has a ‘body’, but one of a very different nature and with very different powers from the physical body he has left behind. Soon after, things begin to happen. Others come to meet and to help him. He glimpses the spirits of relatives and friends who have already died and a loving, warm spirit of a kind he has never encountered before-a being of light- appears before him. This being asks him a question non-verbally- to make him evaluate his life- and helps him along by showing him a panoramic instantaneous playback of the major events of his life. Then he finds that he must go back to earth, that the time for his death has not yet come. At this point, he resists, for by now he is taken up by his experiences in the afterlife and does not want to return. He is overwhelmed by intense feelings of joy, love and peace. Despite his attitude, though, he somehow reunites with his physical body and lives.

Adapted from Moody, R. A. (1975) Life after Life

The NDE man appears to be a spectator in the flurry of activities around him because
Question 6.Explanation:
This can be seen in paragraph 1, sentence 2 through 4.

‘…he hears himself pronounced dead by his doctor. He begins to hear an uncomfortable noise ,a loud ringing or buzzing and at the same time, feels himself moving very rapidly through a dark tunnel. After this, he suddenly finds himself outside of his own physical body, but still in the immediate physical environment and he sees his own body from a distance as though he is a spectator’.

Options.Value: To make conjectures about what happens after death
To know a little about what happens in the world of the dead
For one to experience the sensation of dying and living again
For the dead to return and tell their experiences

Question 11.Question:
The passage below has gaps numbered 11 to 20 .Immediately following each gap, four options are provided. Choose the most appropriate option for each gap.

Before any detailed analysis begins, the first thing to do with the raw data is to check through the field record books and questionnaires for any …11….[A. mistakes B. events C. records D. odds], inconsistencies and incompleteness. In some cases, it may be possible to correct any discovered shortcomings. When it is not possible to carry out these …12 … [A plants B. corrections C. expectations D.possibilities], a visit to the field may even be necessary. It should however be realized that it is not very often that a revisit is possible.

In most scientific ….13…. [A. questionnaires B. data C. experiments D. conclusions], such revisits are clearly impossible. This is true of many surveys too. A road traffic survey …14… [A. classified B. precoded C.conducted D.experimented] to find out the amount and frequency of daily traffic between two towns cannot be expected to be …15…[A. observed B. produced C. undertaken D. reproducible ]. There is no way of going back to check whether the number of vehicles reported for any particular hour is correct or not. With open –ended questions, the …16…. [A. methods B. responses C. errors D. conclusions] have to be classified into relatively small number of groups. The process of classifying answer and of sometimes identifying them by number and letter is called …17….[ A. encoding B. recording C.coding D. recoding]. When close-ended questions are used, it is possible to code all the possible answers before they are actually received. This is called …18…[A. recoding B. coding C. precoding D. encoding]. What is done, a check through the answers for proper classification, numbering and lettering is still called for at this stage. This whole process of checking through questionnaires and notebooks is called …19 … [A. listing B. posting C. editing D. auditing]. Collected data will eventually have to be used in drawing …20 … [A. analogies B. examples C. references D. conclusions] and writing a report about the population from which it came.

--11--
Question 11.Explanation: In the sentence that follows, the one with the gap, reference is made to correction of shortcomings that may be discovered in the process of checking the data: mistakes, inconsistence and incompleteness are shortcomings that can be corrected. Odd is a ratio of a probability which probably can’t be corrected.

Options.Value: Plants
Corrections
Expectations
Possibilities

Options.Value: The volume and speed of traffic on the roads increased with the advent of cars, motorcycles and lorries.
There were no roads before the advent of cars and motorcycles and so people had to be mechanically minded

Question 21.Question:
PASSAGE

By 1910, the motor car was plainly conquering the highway. The private car was now part of every rich man’s establishment, although its price made it as yet an impossible luxury for most of the middle class. But for the adventuresome youth, there was the motorcycle, a fearsome invention producing accidents and ear-splitting noises. Already, the dignified carriages and smart pony traps were beginning to disappear from the roads and coachmen and grooms, unless mechanically minded, were finding it more difficult to make a living.

The roads, which had gone to sleep since the coming of the railway, now awoke to feverish activity. Cars and motorcycles dashed along them at speeds which rivaled those of the express trains and the lorry began to appear. Therefore, the road system was compelled to adapt itself to a volume and speed of traffic for which it had never been intended. Its complete adaptation was impossible; but the road surface was easily transformed and, during the early years of the century, the dustiness and greasiness of the highways were lessened by tar-spraying. To widen and straighten the roads and get rid of blind corners and every steep gradient were tasks which had scarcely been tackled before 1914. The situation was worst of all in towns where not only was any large scheme of road widening usually out of the question, but also were crowding and danger were all too frequently increased by the short-sighted eagerness of town authorities in laying down tramlines.

Yet it was not only the road system that was in need of re adjustment; the nervous system of those who used and dwelt by the roads suffered. The noises caused by the conversion of the roads into speed ways called for a corresponding tightening up of the nerves; and especially in the towns, the pedestrian who wished to preserve life and limb was compelled to keep his attention continually on the stretch to practice himself in estimates of the speed of approaching vehicles and to run or jump for his life if he ventured off the pavement.

The writer seems to suggest that
Question 21.Explanation:
This can be seen in paragraph 2, sentences 2 and 3

‘Cars and motorcycles dashed along them at speeds which rivaled those of the express trains and the lorry began to appear. Therefore, the road system was compelled to adapt itself to a volume and speed of traffic for which it had never been intended’.

Options.Value: Town authorities laying down tramlines
Coachmen and grooms who choose to become mechanics
Coachmen and grooms adaptable to the new technology
Those amenable to change and development

Question 32.Question:

Provided.

……. told of his impending arrival, I worked hard to make his short stay very comfortable

As much/as
At least as/but

Question 33.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

The weather is probably…… appealing for people who live in Jos …….for foreigners.

Obliterate
Eulogize
Obstruct

Question 34.Question:

Ado tried to……all memory of his dead father.

Costed
Cost
Have cost

Question 35.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

This imposing edifice……a fortune to build.
Question 35.Explanation: The past tense and past participle of ‘cost’ remains ‘cost’. It is wrong to say ‘costed’.

Options.Value: Has/has
Have/has
Have/have
Has/have

Question 36.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

Three quarters of the hostel…..been painted and three quarters of the students …..moved in.
Question 36.Explanation: The first verb will agree with the subject in terms of numbers close to it and so will the second verb.

Options.Value: Respect
Regard
Disregard
Consideration

Question 37.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

They let him go in ……of his age.
Question 37.Explanation: There are certain words which are followed by certain preposition in a fixed way. In respect is suitable followed by ‘of’ unlike the words in the other options.

Options.Value: While
By chance
Should
Should in case

Question 38.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

…….you come early to the new house, clean up my flat.
Question 38.Explanation: This sentence could be restructured to be ‘clean up my flat, should you come early to the new house’. Should here links up the two sentences, as a conjunction so it would be wrong to use ‘should in case’ because that would means the use of double adjectives. It is either ‘should’ or ‘in case’ that should be used.

Options.Value: Used
Are used
Were use
Use

Question 39.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

These villagers….. to grow rice.
Question 39.Explanation: ‘Used to’ is an adverb which means formerly, once, and habitually or repeatedly, but possibly no longer. It is different from the verb ‘use’ which has simple past tense and past participle as ‘used’.

Options.Value: Strange
Loving
Caring
Estranged

Question 40.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

When Ajike met her…… husband at the party, she felt like reconciling with him.
Question 40.Explanation: Estranged means having become a stranger of one who formerly was close as a relative, friend, lover, or spouse of course. Ajike could only want to reconcile with a husband. She was no longer close with.

Options.Value: Does not he
Does he
Does he not
Doesn’t he

Question 41.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

He does not seem to know how to solve the problem…….?
Question 41.Explanation: Positive statement attracts negative question tags while negative statement attracts positive question tags. Negative statement have ’no’, ‘not’ or ‘never’ in their verb elements.

Implicate
Replicate
Fabricate

Were
Are

Question 43.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

A wide range of options……. made available to the political parties during the recently concluded elections.
Question 43.Explanation: The determiner ‘a’ before the adjective indicates that the subject is singular, thus the verb must be singular, ‘made’ shows that the action is past, thus the verb must be in the past tense.

Options.Value: Represent
Reconstitute
Reconcile
Recommend

Question 44.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

The meeting was called to …..divergent views on the subjects of a national conference.
Question 44.Explanation: Divergent means diverse and different. This shows that the meeting was aimed at harmonizing these different views on the issue.

Options.Value: Detonate
Insulate
Defuse
Defuse

Question 45.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

The police came early enough to ….. the bomb planted by the rioters.
Question 45.Explanation: Defuse means to remove or disorder a triggering device such as a bomb, or removing its fuse to make it less dangerous.

Options.Value: Is/their
Were/there
Was/its
Are/its

Question 46.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

The government which…….. recruiting…… workers suddenly stopped doing so.
Question 46.Explanation: The government is a singular subject, hence the use of ‘was’ inserted of ‘were’. ‘Stopped’ in the later part of the sentence indicates that the action is past, hence the use of ‘was’ and not ‘is’. Also the sentence indicates that the workers are possession of the government, thus the use of ‘its’ a possessive (pronoun).

Options.Value: Resort to
Switch on
Light up
Fall back on

Question 47.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

They had to ……… the generator when the electricity failed.
Question 47.Explanation: Fall back on someone or something means to rely on someone or something if all else fails switch on means to turn on switch to the ‘on’ position in order to start or enable or device. Note that this statement refers to the switch and not the device.

Options.Value: Rational
Cruel
Secret
Composed

Question 48.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

I do not4 think any sane person would have acted in such a…….manner.
Question 48.Explanation: A sane person is someone in a healthy condition; not deranged acting rationally. A sane person may act secretive and composed and definitely rationally but being cruel is not considered sane.

Options.Value: Has attended
Attend
Attends
Attended

Question 49.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

Neither Agbo nor his parents….. the meetings now
Question 49.Explanation: ‘Now’ in the sentence shows that the action is in the present, thus, the verb must be in the simple present tense (attend). Also when two or more singular subjects are joined by neither-nor, the subject that precedes the verb determines the verb. ‘Parent’ a plural noun preceded the verb, thus, the verb must be plural (attend).

Options.Value: A rapping voice
Bizarre costuming
Immense instrumentation
Some choreographic skill

Question 50.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

Modern dancing has become rather scientific and so acquires …..
Question 50.Explanation: From the options provided, the one which best relates to dancing is option D.

Options.Value: Approaching
Approaches
Approached
Approach

Question 51.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

Of course, we all saw the culprit…….and hit the man on the head.
Question 51.Explanation: In sentence, it is important that tenses are uniform all through. …………….. is in its simple present tense and so should approach.

Options.Value: Photocopy
Photograph
Prototype
Microfilm

Question 52.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

The company director showed the contractor a ……of the proposed office complex.
Question 52.Explanation: A prototype is an original model or type from which copies are made. In this instance, the ‘proposed’ office complex is going to be made as a replica of another building (the prototype).

Options.Value: Would have stood down
Might have stood aside
Should have stepped down
Would have stepped aside

Question 53.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

Had he considered his public image carefully, he …..for his opponent in the election.
Question 53.Explanation: Step aside means to withdraw or retire from a position so as to allow someone else take one’s place.

Options.Value: Up
Across
In
Over

Question 54.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

The editor was not happy that the Nigerian press was hemmed ……
Question 54.Explanation: Item means to enclose or confine. It is usually followed by in, around or about.

Options.Value: Energy
Power
Effort
Grease

Question 55.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

More ……. to your elbow as you campaign for press freedom!
Question 55.Explanation: ‘More power to your elbow’ is used to which someone continued success. However, most people say ‘more grease to your elbow’ which is a wrong expression.

Options.Value: Precocious
Ingenious
Premature
Preconceived

Question 56.Question:
In this question, fill each gap with the most appropriate option from the list

A child that shows mature characteristics at an early age may be described as …..
Question 56.Explanation: Precocious means characterized by exceptionally early development or maturity or exhibiting advanced skills at an abnormally early age.

Options.Value: Misread
Reassign
Competent
Compel

Question 63.Question:
In this question, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) or phrase in italics.

Amina’s performance in the examination surpassed my expectations.
Question 63.Explanation:
Was disappointing

Surpass one’s expectation means to be or do something to a degree greater than one excepts or imagines. Thus, when one does less, it is disappointing and unsatisfactory.

Options.Value: Evil
Open
Cryptic
Ignoble

Question 64.Question:
In this question, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) or phrase in italics.

As these boys never act in public, the police are now worried about their covert activities.
Question 64.Explanation: Covert means secret or hidden. Its antonyms include open, exposed, explicit, public, visible, undisguised and clear.

Options.Value: Unexcited
Excited
On fire
Surprised

Question 65.Question:
In this question, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) or phrase in italics.

The town was all agog at his unexpected return
Question 65.Explanation: Agog means in eager desire. Its antonyms include unexcited, unagitated, unstirred and unturbulent.

Options.Value: A hot
An inclement
A temperate
A stable

Question 66.Question:
In this question, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) or phrase in italics.

Some equatorial areas have a sultry climate.
Question 66.Explanation: Sultry means characterized by oppressive heat and humidity. Its antonyms include mild, cold-temperate, light and intemperate.

Options.Value: Simplicity
Shortage
Complexity
Spectrum

Question 67.Question:
In this question, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) or phrase in italics.

The journalist’s write-up contained a plethora of detail.
Question 67.Explanation: Plethora means an excessive amount or number. Its antonyms include shortage, insufficiency, inadequacy, shortfall and deficit.

Options.Value: Bravery
Vitality
Energy
Senility

Question 68.Question:
In this question, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) or phrase in italics.

In the latter part of his life, the famous soldier showed signs of youthfulness.
Question 68.Explanation: Youthfulness means the vitality characteristic of youths. Its antonyms include oldness, dotage, and old age.

Options.Value: Contestable
Credible
Incomprehensible
Unimaginable

Question 69.Question:
In this question, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) or phrase in italics.

It is inconceivable that the rat devoured the cat.
Question 69.Explanation: Inconceivable means totally unlikely. Its antonyms include possible, imaginable, conceivable and thinkable.

Options.Value: Inconsiderate
Decisive
Anxious
Ambitious

Question 70.Question:
In this question, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) or phrase in italics.

All wondered why the principal was ambivalent about the students future.
Question 70.Explanation: Ambivalent means unable to decide about what course to follow. Its antonyms include decisive, deciding, resolute and conclusive.

Options.Value: Elements
Fundamentals
Basics
Theories

Question 71.Question:
In this question, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) or phrase in italics.

The teacher taught the rudiments of Chemistry to the first grade.
Question 71.Explanation: Rudiments mean a fundamental principle or still, especially in a field of learning. Its antonyms include trivia and details.

Options.Value: Artlessness
Friendliness
Incredulity
Stupidity

Question 72.Question:
In this question, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) or phrase in italics.

In this naivety, he believed all the stories his friend told him.
Question 72.Explanation: Naivety means lack of sophistication and experience. Its antonyms include incredulity, skepticism, dubiousness and doubtfulness.

Options.Value: A regular
An annual
A difficult
An easy

Question 73.Question:
In this question, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) or phrase in italics.

Updating the Board’s brochure is an arduous task.
Question 73.Explanation: Arduous means characterized by physical effort to the point of exhaustion. Its antonyms include easy, effortless and undemanding.

Options.Value: Brief
Interesting
Boring
Unending

Question 74.Question:
In this question, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) or phrase in italics.

The lecture seemed interminable.
Question 74.Explanation: Interminable means existing without interruption or end. Its antonyms include short, brief, clipped and shortened.

Options.Value: Promoted it
Squashed it
Initiated it
Stopped it

Question 75.Question:
In this question, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) or phrase in italics.

Had I known about their plan much earlier, I would have nipped it in the bud.
Question 75.Explanation: Nip in the bud means to stop something at an early stage, or thoroughly check something.

Options.Value: Pleasant
Perfect
Pernicious
Pertinent

Question 76.Question:
In this question, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) or phrase in italics.

What a harmless thought he has!
Question 76.Explanation: Harmless means not causing or capable of causing harm. Its antonyms include harmful, noxious, baneful, deadly, pestilent and insidious.

Options.Value: Indecision
Enthusiasm
Indifference
Disinclination

Question 77.Question:
In this question, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word(s) or phrase in italics.

There is much apathy towards reading among students nowadays.
Question 77.Explanation: Apathy means lack of interest or enthusiasm. Its antonyms include enthusiasm, pursuit and interest.

Options.Value: Should your brother come with us tomorrow?
Should our brother come with us tomorrow?
Should Ado’s sister come with us tomorrow?
Should my sister come with us tomorrow?

Question 78.Question:
In this question, the word in capital letters has emphatic stress. Choose the option that best fits the expression in the sentence.

YOUR sister should come with us tomorrow.
Question 78.Explanation: The word which contrast with the emphasized word ‘your’ is ‘our’.

Options.Value: Where did they fly to?
Did they go to Abuja by road?
How will they get to Abuja?
Did they fly to Jos?

Question 79.Question:
In this question, the word in capital letters has emphatic stress. Choose the option that best fits the expression in the sentence.

They FLEW to Abuja.
Question 79.Explanation: In this question, the emphasized word ‘FLEW’ is the answer to the question in option A. the emphasized word determines the interrogative pronoun that will be used in asking the question. If the emphasized word was ABUJA, then the question would have started with ‘where’.

Options.Value: Did your neighbour fracture his thigh while playing football?
Did your neighbour break his leg while playing tennis?
Did your neighbour play football yesterday?
Did your neighbour break his hand when playing football?

Question 80.Question:
In this question, the word in capital letters has emphatic stress. Choose the option that best fits the expression in the sentence.

My neighbor BRUISED his thigh while playing football
Question 80.Explanation: In answering question which emphatic stress, the option that has a word that contracts with the word emphasized is the right answer. The word ‘fracture’ in option d contrast with ‘BRUISED’ which was emphasized. Also note that in option A, break also contrast with bruise but football was changed to tennis, making it a wrong option.
